column4: ok any experts here who have done work with 915resolution driver/tool?
I'm not so expert, but I did my laptop work with 915 resolution
restart in safe mode (it's one of the option in GRUB when you start your computer). Then from the terminal, try to configure correctly 915resolution and xorg.conf
I don't know that, you can try to search. I have 10 seconds and it's good for me
ok lemme first explain the mistake I did while configuring 915resolution
instead of using a mode which I didn't want to use, I mentioned the mode which I wanted to use
later on, although I got the hang & mentioned instead the mode I didn't want to use, what should I do?

what I did is to search for 915resolution modes to find my resolution (that 4c or things like that). Then I configured 915resolution (there is a configuration file I don't remember where, but I can chek) to use that mode (4c or whatever) that I want to use with resolution 640x480. Then I edited file /etc/X11/xorg.conf and set as resolution only 640x480, 24 bit.
I did tht one, then I also the /etc/init.d/915resolution start

yeah that one. It could be a good thing to install "BUM" (BootUp Manager) to check that 915resolution is always booted with a high priority (before gmd and graphic server). BUM it's a good gui program
BUM is in universe, multiverse or some other repository?
boot in safe mode and try to do what I told you... change that 915resolution config file and change /etc/X11/xorg.conf to use only one resolution, the one in 915resolution config file

I don't remember, just check. I think it's in the normal repo. Just try to reboot in safe mode, change those 2 files (915resolution and xorg.conf) and then try a 'startx' to start the x server and check that it starts in the correct way. If so, install BUM and ensure that 915resolution is booted, possibly before other processes
